We've got two types of extra specs - in-tree and out-of-tree. For the former, I'd much rather define these as Python objects since that's what I'm used to working with expect and it prevents people thinking they can go and hack on the schema willy-nilly. For the latter, I think YAML does the job since it's far more accessible to end-users (they don't need to learn Python).
Yeah, totally do the in-tree stuff in code. We're in agreement here.

++ microversion, but I would also expect a granny switch conf opt to turn validation on or off wholesale.

In fact, I would eventually expect that conf option to allow several levels of validation. At least:
- strict (unknown keys are bounced - I'm asserting all possible legal keys have been registered)
- loose (unknown keys are ignored)
- off

> Microversions aren't an all-or-nothing affair. I can make a request
 > to the '/flavors/{flavor_id}/os-extra_specs' API using an older

Right, I get that. That works until we cut a new microversion that affects the flavor API.

 > In addition, I'm not sure why you'd want to opt out of this
 > long-term.

As noted above, I can definitely see a phase where I want to take advantage of the validation you're writing for in-tree extra specs without having to write YAML files for the outside stuff.

 > It's a useful feature and while there may be a small bit
 > of work required by operators to configure their YAML file for any
 > out of tree extra specs they may have

It's not necessarily a small bit of work, depending on the situation/deployment/etc.

I can also see a use case where I want to define a flavor with a truly one-off extra spec that's not appropriate to include in my long-term validation. I sure don't want to have to go lay down a YAML file so I can execute my command and then remove the file again. But I still want the other 99% of my extra specs validated according to the in-tree and YAML validators I've taken pains to set up.

Anyway, I'm not going to die on a hill for this; I just think it would make some things more user friendly and it's really cheap to do.

My concern is, when we introduce a subsequent microversion, you wouldn't be able to opt out of the extra spec validation and also get the benefit of the new feature.

But hm, yeah, I get what you mean about config-driven API behavior. That's a weird one. I don't suppose a qparam...?

Can't do that. That would imply config-driver API behavior, which is something we try avoid nowadays. It's possible that we could make a mistake or forget some extra specs when implementing the validators, but those issues should be fixed with bugfix patches, not by disabling validation

> My concern is, when we introduce a subsequent microversion, you
 > wouldn't be able to opt out of the extra spec validation and also
 > get the benefit of the new feature.

Microversions aren't an all-or-nothing affair. I can make a request to the '/flavors/{flavor_id}/os-extra_specs' API using an older microversion and then use the newer one for the rest of the flow. In addition, I'm not sure why you'd want to opt out of this long-term. It's a useful feature and while there may be a small bit of work required by operators to configure their YAML file for any out of tree extra specs they may have, that's a once off and no different from e.g. having to migrate off deprecated features.

Also note that there is precedent for these changes. A recent API microversion from gmann (I've to dig out the exact version) introduced strict API validation. Anyone who started using this new API microversion with additional keys would suddenly start seeing failure. This seems like the exact same thing.

 > But hm, yeah, I get what you mean about config-driven API behavior.
 > That's a weird one. I don't suppose a qparam...?

This should mention what happens when the control plane is updated before (some of) the computes. In such cases, the computes (where many extra specs are ultimately processed) will have a different idea of what's valid than the API. In most cases it's additive -- the API will allow things that the compute can't handle -- but in some cases it might go the other way.

If the developer of $new-thing is doing their job right, there ought to be a request filter or similar that prevents a new flavor from landing on an old compute.

But there are more complex cases to be considered. Like if we add extra/stricter validation to a key that already existed, we can't enforce that check until we're sure all the computes have been upgraded.
When we implement such stricter validation for an existing key wouldn't that be in a new microversion? If yes then the old microversion still can be used to use the old spec with old computes.

What if there is an in-tree validator with "name='hw:numa_cpu.{id}'," and there is an out of tree validator with 'name='hw:numa_cpu.0',' or with "name='hw:numa_cpu.{node_id}'," ?

I buy your argument. It is similar to my argument that yaml files in the package directory while editable we don't expect that will be edited by anybody. So while there will be ways to circumvent precedence we don't expect the deployer to do it.

We match two different ways. First, we do a plain string lookup that handles extra specs without parameters. Since we don't allow duplicates names, that will mean this is a non-issue for this case. If that search fails, we iterate through all the registered extra specs looking for a name pattern that matches what we have. Since this is linear, we'll just sort things so that in-tree validators come first. I don't think there should be any reason to override in-tree extra specs (it's not cross-compatible) so I don't think we need to worry about the case you suggested.

But I'm wondering if we need to modify this parameter in place. For example if multiple extensions had been processing the same port, later extensions would not see the tags added in db_data. Is this parameter supposed to be modified or are all extensions expected to ignore db_data and re-query their port data from the db?

No. This argument is the dictionary representation of the db object that was added to the DB by the plugin. I have implemented several ML2 extensions and have never extended this dictionary directly. Besides, one extension shouldn't be making assumptions about what other extensions did before it. An extension shouldn't make assumptions about what other extensions are configured and / or in what order they are called. That would lead to non-deterministic behavior

releasenotes/notes/support-glance-multip.message:
this case isn't handled during validation
in the current implementation it will error out with InvalidStoreException if image_service:store_id is null
is it worth mentioning here that 'image_service:store_id' can only be set when multiple glance stores are configured?

I suggest replacing this with:

This release includes support for Glance multiple stores.  An operator
may now specify which Glance store will be used when a volume is
uploaded to Glance as an image.  Some details about this feature:

* This feature is not directly user-facing.  To enable it, an operator
  must add the field ``image_service:store_id`` in the volume-type
  extra-specs.  The value of the field is a valid store identifier
  (``id``) configured in Glance, which may be discovered by making a
  ``GET /v2/info/stores`` call to the Image Service API.
* If ``image_service:store_id`` is not set in the extra-specs for a
  volume-type, then any volume of that type uploaded as an image will
  be uploaded to the default store in Glance.
* The ``image_service:store_id`` can only be set in the extra-specs
  for a volume-type when multiple glance stores are configured.
* Cinder validates proposed Glance store identifiers by contacting
  Glance at the time the ``image_service:store_id`` is added to a
  volume-type's extra-specs.  Thus the Image Service API must be
  available when a volume-type is updated.

It is important to know the
architecture limitations also, as I think the stretched architecture has strict availability limitations for autonomous sites remaining disconnected from other partition(s). Multi-master cluster will not allow writing to a minority partition w/o quorum. And that would be a blocker, had we wanted "Always Available Fully Autonomous" edge cloud sites, right? So could we please explicitly state the architecture limitations and assumptions for the proposed change. E.g.: autonomous remote sites may be not always operating in write/allow-everything mode. Read-only restrictions may be required for some cases, which means local management of remote sites will be restricted for such cases.

will add that.  Note I dont even think shared galera is very "edge-" like at all.   "edge" typically implies arbitrary numbers of points along that edge in my observation.   this idea is definitely only a handful of overclouds type of thing.   Federated keystone is also potentially going to become very viable in stein which also may make this effort not worth it, will update the "alternatives" section.

yea we'll probably want to figure out how we want to properly address this. Techincally if the internalapi network has routes to the other internalapi networks it can remain on the same network.  There are likely other security considerations that will have to be solved with this. Like iptables rules or whatever.

one nice thing about it being on a different network than the "local" database is that I can keep all the port numbers the same (e.g. galera ports, xinetd ports, mysql ports).   It would probably be burdensome to have all of these be changed particularly because galera has about five ports of its own.

Would we solve for when the galera instances lose connectivity with the other "global" ones with the resource agent? Would this resource agent actually handle putting the system in Read-Only until connectivity is restored?

We do want to do that also, yes.   We haven't built any proof of concept for that yet, however and also I need to know if we need to change the relationship to pacemaker to handle that or not.     I can mention this capability here as a paragraph regarding HA.   The feature would take place entirely on the pacemaker/ resource agent side so I don't know that a new blueprint would be needed but we need to somehow list this as a "fairly important to have / dont have it yet" kind of item here.
Could you please also describe the "local" to "global" replication design in a separate section, for the stretched galera cluster case?
can you give an example of what you mean here?
I was wondering how would multi-master galera cluster support this scenario in the stretched cluster? Could we have a dedicated section describing that?

did it miss the example solution name?..
Do we want to limit the spec for Keystone as we mention only it?
this sounds like the same question.   are you looking for basically what happens on Galera when someone persists data to a database, how does it get to the other nodes ?

That, and which directions - is it syncs data for all sides, or limited to edge to central sites, for example? I think these architecture constraints should be clearly defined in a separate section of the spec.

Did you see the HA section I added?  I can add the above verbiage if it helps, I already included your previous phrasing regarding R/W availability.  Can you comment on the most recent version in the HA section?

I've been mostly thinking of just having the known architecture constraints noted for that replication/HA section. And yes, I'm thinking of its applicability for the edge cases and imposed limitations. Nothing than that, just to set the expectations clear for anyone might be willing to build fully autonomous Edge architectures off that base solution.

For example, a statement can be like:

"Because of galera multi-master syncs in every direction, it cannot be Always Available, which is always allowing RW operations including isolated/partitioned remote sites. For such a case, consider other solutions based on causal or real-time causal consistency models, leveraging one-way synchronization and data replication mechanisms."


I hope that makes sense to note that...
But thanks for already created that section! :)

Galera is multi-master so data syncs in every direction, the main point of sophistication it provides is that it certifies the data to be written by a transaction (a "write set") across all nodes in the cluster before considering the transaction to be complete, that is, before it tells the calling application that the "commit" is done (e.g. it blocks).  If any node states that the incoming writeset is in conflict with its own writeset, the transaction is rejected as a concurrency error.  Openstack applications all have retry logic for the points where this scenario is likely to occur under normal use (most notably Neutron when it allocates resources like IP numbers and such).  For a simple CRUD application like Keystone, in the extremely unlikely case that two users are persisting conflicting changes to the same row at the identical moment to two different Galera nodes, one of the users would get an error response, and they could then try the operation again.    None of this is new to openstack, that's how it works now (with the caveat that tripleo is currently routing Galera traffic to a single node at a time - the secton here on "Galera runs as Multi Master" addresses this aspect).

While the certification stage is synchronous with the commit, by default the actual write of the data to all nodes proceeds asynchronously so the performance hit is mitigated (that part can also be made synchronous for a very critical section but this is not generally needed).

This general behavior of Galera is not new information for TripleO/Openstack , I can add more introductory paragraphs above the "Galera Multi Master" section if that helps.

...and that basically may be another nice note wrt how we are going to address that known architecture limitation for fully autonomous/always available Edge sites in future (thinking of the stretched galera cluster as a dependency for the Edge story)
thanks! now I think all of my comments are addressed!
We talked recently about this and decided that we could pursue having different service users per overcloud. This would address this issue. Could this be included in the blueprint?
still hoping to see this addressed in the blueprint
done, let me know what you think, I only have a cursory understanding of the keystone tables.

The problem description doesn't fully describe shared vs global, and why we need a global db.

I view a global db as described in this spec as significantly more complex than a shared db. Consider that we could just deploy a 3 node cluster as a separate stack that only runs the necessary services for a galera cluster: pacemaker, galera, haproxy, docker, etc.

The connection details for that shared database could then be provided as inputs into other overcloud stacks that are running OpenStack services that actually intend to use the shared database (keystone, glance, etc). While other OpenStack services could use the local database deployed as part of their overcloud stack.

After reading through the spec though, it seems the proposal is to instead deploy 2 galera services on every controller node in each stack: one local galera service, and one global service. 

This differs from what I would call shared where each stack has only 1 database service, and then a separate stack exists just for the shared database.

I think the shared model is significantly less complex than what is proposed here, for example, it could possibly be done with no changes to resource agents, or any of the additional bootstrapping logic. Only small changes to TripleO would be needed, such as a parameter to override the keystone db connection value.

What I'd like to understand is why we need the global solution that is fully explained here, or if the simpler shared model would also work. Or perhaps these are separate use cases that exist on their own.

It would be nice to articulate though why the global model is needed. It could be it's due to location and latency requirements? I think we need to capture some of that in the problem description. Because as it's worded now, I couldn't explain why the global model is needed vs a much simpler shared db model.

Note that this does not attempt to solve edge cases. It is more related towards having some multi-region support out of the box, which would be useful for linking a few big-sized data centers. We currently don't have an edge proposal for Keystone in TripleO, and I actually don't think we can even provide one here. There are some proposals in the keystone community and we should explore helping the implementation of those in order to get that to be deployable in TripleO.

I think this effectively addresses our immediate needs related to multi-region support for some customers, and I think it would be nice to have this feature. but I agree that we need more description of the problem and alternatives in the spec in order to fill in other folks and document what's being done.

As far as the global vs. shared use cases, I want to get Fabio's etc. input into some of the use cases that were discussed.   I believe a major concern is that a particular overcloud be able to function on its own in the absense of the other overclouds, e.g. network partitions, a concern which would apply to the concept of a shared database as well.   Latency is also definitely a concern that was brought up when we first were working this out - it's generally not a desirable architecture, both from a network as well as a security point of view, to have an application server accessing its datastore remotely, especially if it's a relational database.    

I would ask, if we are looking at shared database only, why we don't instead consider that the whole Keystone service is remoted from the individual overclouds.   This would be more appropriate from both a security pov as well as latency, since the Keystone API presents a secure, coarse-grained API, in comparison to the fine-grained back-and-forth that occurs between an application server and its database.   And this would be even simpler than shared database, especially for upgrades, because we wouldn't need to have multiple keystone services on different overclouds remoting to a database over the external network.     

At the Keystone edge discussion in Denver, all of the architectures discussed seemed to include that a particular Openstack stack would have a local Keystone instance; that is, even in the "federated" case, there still was a cascade of identity information from a remote identity service to a local one.   I believe a central assumption of these architectures is that a particular openstack stack is able to operate in the absense of network connectivity to other remote nodes.   This is one of the key rationales for the "edge" concept as a whole - one of placing the services physically closer to the work being done and able to work in partial isolation from the rest of the system.

Basically, if we are going to go for "remote DB access is required", I think architecturally that makes more sense for the Keystone service itself to be remote, but I think in either case, by requiring remote access we are adding the latency and network fallibility that I think "edge" is intended to solve.

Both approaches have pro and cons.

A shared db becomes more easily a single point of failure and requires more hardware and more careful deployment strategy (specially from a network perspective). I agree it's much easier to deploy and configure with its own stack.

A global db, while more complex to deploy and bootstrap, has the benefit to have a local node in each location that would allow read-only operation to continue without interruption even if the network to other locations is disrupted.

In context we need to think that whoever is going to deploy such complex scenario is aiming to have no single point of failures and max availability.

I also agree with Mike that exposing a DB over the network represent a security challenge and we should avoid that if possible at all.

Latency represents a potential problem regardless of which path we take and only testing can tell us how far we can distribute some deployments.

We cannot have a keystone remote service (as indicated in another comment). We need to be able to sync other db/tables as well. Keystone is the one currently being requested the most, but other users have asked for glance DB sync as well (to share images), so we need to be a bit more considerate about the "remotizing services" concept.

> yes, we are trying to solve the problem of one keystone shared
 > among many overclouds, without requiring external network access
 > for local read-only operations, and additionally that those
 > keystone services are available when you can't get to the other
 > overclouds on the network.   this is the largely same thing

Once again, such an autonomy requirement is outside of MVP  and we should redesign the spec to clarify that we have no such a requirement yet. Only multiple control planes can provide that, so CRUDs will keep working locally as well as remotely.

 > keystone federation promises to do, although federation requires
 > more heavily that there be an external identity provider that is
 > reachable, and when I spoke to people most tuned into keystone
 > federation, they expressed that the global DB idea is still useful
 > as a stopgap while federation use cases mature.
 > 
 > 
 > It would be helpful if other folks here, like those who I met at
 > summit, have been on calls with , etc. could chime in why we think
 > this is useful...my involvement is that I was trying to implement
 > the above use case that was presented to me.

yes, we are trying to solve the problem of one keystone shared among many overclouds, without requiring external network access for local read-only operations, and additionally that those keystone services are available when you can't get to the other overclouds on the network.   this is the largely same thing keystone federation promises to do, although federation requires more heavily that there be an external identity provider that is reachable, and when I spoke to people most tuned into keystone federation, they expressed that the global DB idea is still useful as a stopgap while federation use cases mature.


It would be helpful if other folks here, like those who I met at summit, have been on calls with , etc. could chime in why we think this is useful...my involvement is that I was trying to implement the above use case that was presented to me.

Let's make sure the actual problems addressed by the global db is captured in the description.

For exposing a DB over the network, are the security concerns here specific to Edge? I'm trying to understand this, because wouldn't one edge location have the potential to connect to a a global db cluster member in a different edge location? I don't just mean at the cluster level, but potentially at the API -> DB level through the db connection string.

Isn't this why the spec mentions that these services are going to be possibly routed on the external network? I think this needs clarification.

This is why I asked earlier, what construct will exist to ensure that nodes prefer their "local" member of the global db cluster? Will each edge location have it's own VIP that only points to it's local member?

Added Morgan and Adam as experts in the subject area (at least for Keystone Federation aspects).

 > As far as the global vs. shared use cases, I want to get Fabio's

 > believe a major concern is that a particular overcloud be able to
 > function on its own in the absense of the other overclouds, e.g.
 > network partitions, a concern which would apply to the concept of a

IIUC, a global database represents the single control plane case, which is also accepted by the upstream Edge WG as an MVP for OpenStack. It is also known, that a single control plane cannot provide local autonomy in the face of network partitions. So when a minority partition of the global DB stops, any CRUD operations over control plane will stop function there as well. IIUC, the global DB model was the recommended case for Keystone Federation that Adam and Morgan evaluated and presented at the summit in Berlin (or was it local databases that share nothing?..)? The case requires no external data replication tooling aside of the built-in capabilities of the global DB. That is totally unlikely to the shared DB case though, which would require a sophisticated data replication and conflicts resolving tooling!

Let's please clarify this global DB case in the spec? Thanks!

The shared DB case is not for MVP and it is probably makes no sense to propose or discuss it this early for that spec. Let's keep it for later post-MVP phases.

I'll let Adam and Morgan to comment on that please,
but my take from the Berlin summit was exactly an opposite, which is no local/shared databases required at all as we expect zero autonomy for disconnected sites, but a global DB only instead that natively replicates those unified UIDs for Keystone federation?.. I may be totally wrong though, and that could have been all about local databases that share nothing :) Anyway, at least that is clear that no shared databases are welcome yet!

 > case, there still was a cascade of identity information from a
 > remote identity service to a local one.   I believe a central

 > "edge" concept as a whole - one of placing the services physically
 > closer to the work being done and able to work in partial isolation

right, but support for autonomous operations of muiltiple control planes had been postponed for post-MVP phases so please let omit that from the spec.

 > 
 > Basically, if we are going to go for "remote DB access is
 > required", I think architecturally that makes more sense for the
 > Keystone service itself to be remote, but I think in either case,
 > by requiring remote access we are adding the latency and network
 > fallibility that I think "edge" is intended to solve.

I think that we will have that fallibility based on latency constraints anyway, either as a "hidden" limitation of a global database to replicate over high latency, or as a visible for DB clients limitation to access DB remotely over high latency.

More details about the actual use cases would be great. Even if the global model is desired for those cases, we could still use separate stacks. A galera global stack could deploy 1 node in each desired edge location, which just the services needed for the galera global stack. I still think that would simplify things greatly as a lot of the complexity in the spec seems to be around the requirement of running and bootstrapping 2 galera services on each database node.

However, using separate stacks would require more nodes overall. So there may be something about the use cases that makes that less desirable, etc.

I think accessing a remote database is somewhat common today, given the ability to break up services among different roles where a standalone database role is actually desirable in some deployments.

As you indicate, this is probably not what is needed for Edge though.

Some of the additional problems that the global solution here proposes to solve include:

* latency
* isolation in case of partition from other clusters/stacks

Can we add these to the problem description so it's more clear why this solution is needed? I think the shared case is something that might stand on its own, separate from edge.

For the latency requirement, is there anything in the spec to ensure that nodes from a given overcloud prefer to connect to the global galera nodes that are part of their same overcloud? For instance, stack2 api nodes perfer stack2 global galera nodes, etc.

> For exposing a DB over the network, are the security concerns here specific to Edge? I'm trying to understand this, because wouldn't one edge location have the potential to connect to a a global db cluster member in a different edge location? I don't just mean at the cluster level, but potentially at the API -> DB level through the db connection string.

that's not an assumption, because the cluster communication used by Galera can be configured to use a different network than that of the port 3306 network used by MySQL for regular client connections.   This is something I should probably try to achieve in the POC / patch I'm working on, because at the moment yes everything is binding to the external network, including the haproxy vip.   It doesn't actually have to be that way, everything could remain on the internal network (though I'd probably have to bump mysql to port 3307 to not conflict with the existing mysql services) except for the galera cluster communication.   The galera communication can and should be set up to require SSL certificates for everything.    There is support for SSL client connections from services on port 3306 as well, however.

Still, from a security POV it's not a standard practice to have galera cluster communication on an external network, so there's that.  In support of your argument overall, MySQL databases exposed on internet port 3306 are somewhat common, even though they are a neverending source of hundreds of CVEs per year, and a document like https://severalnines.com/blog/how-secure-galera-cluster-8-tips basically supports the more traditional architecture you suggest, that is, the galera cluster is private and port 3306 is public.

Latency is the other concern.    Read-only operations from each MySQL database have no additional overhead regarding the rest of the cluster, so having these always be local connections is preferable.    

So we have a wishy-washy security argument, a reasonable latency argument, and a pretty central HA argument / edge for local database argument.     What should we do with each of these?

Well, they would be good to list in the problem description.

Further though, what I'm really interested in is the actual user/operator use case here.

An operator wouldn't choose to deploy a stretch global galera database across separate overcloud deployments for "low latency". They already have that by just using a galera db local to their own cluster. There's no need for global anything.

So what is the actual use case?

As a cloud user I want to create a user in Keystone in one edge cloud and be able to login with that user at a different edge cloud.

As an operator, I want to revoke a Keystone token in one edge cloud, have that token be revoked for all edge clouds.

Are those the actual problems we are trying to solve with this? Right now we have a prescriptive solution (global galera cluster) that doesn't solve any articulated problems for users/operators. That's what I'd like to make sure we all agree we are aiming to solve with this effort.

Per my earlier comment, I don't totally see how this configuration would prevent a node in one edge location from connecting to the global galera service cluster member in a different location.

We might need a new way to configure the db connection string to not use a VIP. Don't we just want the Keystone service to always and only connect to it's global member that is local?
Ok, I think I see how this works based on the implementation patch. It's a VIP per deployment with Haproxy configured with only a single backend which is the local node cluster member.

Michael, can you expand on this a little so folks can understand this better? Seems that the description is a little vague, and folks will need to read these comments or consult the implementation in order to fully grasp what's going on.
so we need the /etc/hosts entries too? Or DNS

They do a little bit of both. Some don't care about DNS and have TripleO manage its own thing; some want full control over the DNS entries. This should be handled in the docs though; we gotta tell folks what exact DNS entries they would need if they want to manage them, and by default persist these values to /etc/hosts for folks that want it to work out of the box.

it can be either, my POC is using /etc/hosts.  Here's the relevant section in my config for "stack1":

      overcloud-controller-0: "stack1-overcloud-controller-0"
      overcloud-controller-1: "stack1-overcloud-controller-1"

      external:
        - 10.0.10.12
        - 10.0.10.13
        - 10.0.10.14

    # on stack1, add /etc/hosts entries pointing to stack2.
    # on stack2, add /etc/hosts entries pointing to stack1.

      - 10.1.10.12 stack2-overcloud-controller-0.external.localdomain stack2-overcloud-controller-0.external
      - 10.1.10.13 stack2-overcloud-controller-1.external.localdomain stack2-overcloud-controller-1.external
      - 10.1.10.14 stack2-overcloud-controller-2.external.localdomain stack2-overcloud-controller-2.external


I don't know operator use cases well enough to know how they  usually do this side of things, but if it's the above, then we can include it in the spec here.

files/functions.message: As you pointed out in IRC, ownership for everything in the directory is being set here, so as long as something is setting FILE_OWNER or FILE_GROUP to www-data when calling the function, this will presumably work as intended.

The semicolon at the end of this command isn't needed. In shell scripting, it's simply a way to terminate a command in lieu of ending the line, in cases where another command will be following on the same line. Still, it doesn't hurt anything and the existing lines below it are already doing the same.

You might also consider using explicit 4-digit file modes, like 0770, making it clearer that the SETGID/SETUID bits are turned off.

specs/train/approved/cpu-resources.rst.message:
A question, so we will explicitly consume VCPU resource for the emulator threads, right?

How can we refuse the non-pinned instance to consume those VCPU when we can mix the pinned and non-pinned instance on the same host?

> A question, so we will explicitly consume VCPU resource for the
 > emulator threads, right?

It's complicated, if we're using 'hw:emulator_threads_policy=isolate' then we need to consume an additional PCPU. If we're using 'hw:emulator_threads_policy=share' then we're going to place these on CPUs from the '[compute] cpu_shared_set' but we don't necessarily need to track this. I personally wanted to drop the 'isolate' policy going forward or rather alias it to 'share', since I think everyone is using the 'share' behavior.

 > How can we refuse the non-pinned instance to consume those VCPU
 > when we can mix the pinned and non-pinned instance on the same
 > host?

As noted, I don't think we need to track these when using the 'share' policy. I wouldn't consume a 'VCPU' per instance.

I guess we needn't refuse that. The operator still need to set aggregate for the hosts which is only running pinned instance. And in the future, the opeartor also needs a aggregate for hosts which accept the PCPU and VCPU mixed instance.

If a host with 12 cpu threads which is used for pinned instance, and it only use `cpu_shared_set=0-3` in stein release, the vcpu_pin_set is empty. In stein release, it reports the number of VCPU based on all available CPU on the host, and let us assume the host already allocated 12 VCPUs for the instances.

After upgrade, we change the inventory of VCPU to the number vcpus in cpu_shared_set, it should be 4 VCPUs in this example, then the allocation for the existed instance (12 vCPUs) will exceed this inventory.

We should have problem for the host which is used for non-pinned instance also. The cpu_shared_set may shrink the existed inventory of VCPU, then leads to over allocation.

One method in my mind is that keeping report both VCPU and PCPU for this case, and asking the operator to update the cpu_shared_set to the all vCPUs for the host which is used for non-pinned instance. (actually, the operator shouldn't set this option for the non-pinned host.)
I'm ok with this assumption, it sounds make sense. Not sure we have enough explain for operator before. Probably we need those detail in the upgrade note.

> If a host with 12 cpu threads which is used for pinned instance, and it only use `cpu_shared_set=0-3` in stein release, the vcpu_pin_set is empty. In stein release, it reports the number of VCPU based on all available CPU on the host, and let us assume the host already allocated 12 VCPUs for the instances.

This is _exceptionally_ unlikely and I've chosen to ignore this possibility. The only reason to define 'cpu_shared_set' in Stein or before is to use emulator thread offloading. The idea behind emulator thread offloading is to isolate the additional work the emulator needs to do from the work the guest OS is doing, mainly for real-time. If you were using 'cpu_shared_set' without 'vcpu_pin_set' then your guest vCPUs can be pinned to any host core including those listed in 'cpu_shared_set'. This would defeat the whole purpose of the feature so I'm relying on people not having done this silly thing :) If we can't rely on this then we need to specify that 'cpu_dedicated_set' is always set, even if it's to an empty list/None, whenever 'cpu_shared_set' is set. That makes upgrade more difficult. See conversation starting here:

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2019-06-18.log.html#t2019-06-18T10:11:47

Do you think this is a reasonable assumption?

this step should be before enabling the prefilter.

If we enable the prefilter first, then we may over-allocate the resource.
This resharp can be triggered by cpu_dedicated_set being set.
Oh, good idea.

.pre-commit-config.yaml.message:
Does this mean pre-commit is going to install flake8 from source rather than from PyPI? That would be a regression in the gate, as it would mean pulling the source from the internet everything vs. installing a wheel from a per-region mirror.

In this patch to nova:

  https://review.opendev.org/#/c/665518

they instead list the linters in the additional_dependencies list for pre-commit. I think that's a better pattern for the use of this tool

That is debatable, but let me explain.

The downside of using flake8 hook from pre-commit itself is that you loose ability to update it automatically via `pre-commit auto-update`.

Yes, there is a performance benefit of using wheel approach, but it should be neglisible.

On the other hand, if we are concerned about performance and extra load caused by explosing of cloning we have two things we can do:

a) mirror linters to opendev.org and use them from there (there are only 5-6 repositories afaik)

b) start caching ~/.cache/pre-commit -- which would induce be a huge performance boost.

Regarding your question about git vs wheel, you are far from being the first to raise it. About an year ago I aked the same myself but after digging a bit I understood why they made this decision. Summary: git can be used as an language agnostic installation method, wheel is only for python. This was the only way they could implement a generic management too, one that knows how to pin versions and to do upgrades.

On Travis I used caching ~/.cache/pre-commit succesfully but I do not know how to do the same with zuul.

Remark: if moving flake8 from standalone repo to core pre-commit-hooks is the only issue, I am more than glad to make it.

I just ran this quickly on one of my SAIOs. And it does indeed delete all the objects. Currently this isn't an issue, as the delete will be replicated via the account replication well before the reaper comes around, so the account would definitely be deleted.

When we add undelete to the mix, what happens if a reseller admin comes in just before the delay_reaping expires, issues an undelete but fails to apply the undelete to only 1 of the account's primary copies. Before account replication syncs the undelete metadata around to the node that missed it, the delay_reaping expires and the reaper happily goes off and deletes _all_ the containers and objects in the account.

This might be an edge case, but it's possible currently and deleting everyones data isn't something we really want. So I feel if we want to support undeleting we need to mitigate this edgecase.

Reaping accounts isn't as common as other activities in Swift, so I wonder if we need to add a quorum check before progressing, or somehow know if at least 1 replication cycle has completed before reaping (but the latter would be harder).
By quorum I mean the reaper, before it goes and acutally reaps the account it asks the other primary nodes for the account if they agree the account is deleted. If a majority quorum agree, it's safe to go and reap.

If this doesnt make sense, I'm happy to discuss it further or even help get it coded :)

If I remember correctly the "deadlock" was if someone went and undeleted an account right on the end time which is valid there wouldn't be a race between the reaper and the undelete doing it's thing.

So add a skew to the reaper, to avoid this situation. So not necessarily a deadlock. Though Swift is eventually consistent so there is no guarantee that the undelete will hit all the primaries. What happens then, we can still end up in the same place.
I probe test for this situation would be great so we can see what happens.

As far as I can see, the reaper doesn't check for a qourum from other primaries, so if the undelete doesn't make it to one primary node before the reaper gets to it (the initial requests fail to hit all primaries and a db replication run doesn't get the put timestamp updated in time) then the reaper running on that non-updated primary will go and delete all the containers and objects. We may need to add some kind of quorum check to the reaper to avoid this situation.

The analysis for this case as below:
				
1. Proxy-server handles and transfers the client's specific headers using generate_request_headers() method(from contoller/base.py) to backend of account-server.
2. The generate_request_headers internally invokes the transfer_headers() method that transfers only metadata specific headers. (i.e. it should contains the 'meta' string into the headers).
3. As per the analysis, we observed that to handle our case we need to use metadata specific header, and hence we used "X-Account-Meta-Undelete".

/COMMIT_MSG.message: what is "new_facade" ?

it's an attribute versioned objects in neutron have to enforce using reader.using / writer.using. This patch is an attempt to allow objects to not set the flag and still correctly open nested subtransactions by detecting in which context it's being executed - the old facade-less or the new facade-ful.

when I created enginefacade, I can't imagine a worse outcome that it created the need to build all new frameworks and complexities in order to have enormously complicated applications sharing between two approaches simultaneously.  How did we get here?   what are the mistakes that were made by me or otherwise?   was the transition to neutron enginefacade just vastly underscoped?

I think indeed the work was underscoped. Another contributor to the need to share two modes is that neutron has enormous number of plugins that are embedded into base plugin code flow. A lot of plugin code explicitly opens subtransactions using begin(nested=True), which is problematic if it's executed from under a reader.using / writer.using that is opened by parent base plugin code from neutron repo. In this case, we mix nesting styles and make the code open two separate transactions with their own persistency scopes. (Changes are committed to database before the parent session context manager exits.)

So we need to deal with both styles working at the same time. The suggestion here is to allow to detect execution context and use the right context manager for nesting without the need to set new_facade attribute to True. Then step by step move plugin code to using the auto-detection wrapper, do the same for base neutron code, then finally kill the wrapper and always use facade.

doc/source/contributor/internals/objects.message: nit: the terms "nested" and "subtransaction" mean explicit, different things in SQLAlchemy (which itself could be a nit with SQLAlchemy :)  but here we are), "nested" with Session refers to a SAVEPOINT so maybe not use that word here since I don't think that's what you're referring towards.

neutron/objects/base.py.message: seems like we can't remove it after all...

I know there's a lot of history here but overall normal usage of the SQLAlchemy ORM there shouldn't really be any "detaching" of objects going on.   I don't recall all the conversations I had with kbenton on this but long term, you should not have to detach objects from sessions.
to check if that maybe flushes everything when no synthetic fields are changed.

the "objects" argument to flush() is a dark corner of the ORM that isn't really a first class API, as it cannot do the "right thing" in many cases.   if using this is part of an interim solution then OK but long term, usage of the SQLAlchemy ORM shouldn't depend on having to flush only parts of the objects in the transaction, this is an antipattern.   I don't know what a "synthetic field" is, it seems awfully complicated.
note that session.refresh() doesn't re-load relationships right now, just column attributes

Thanks Ryan, yep the PTG is the best. Unfortunately neither Xubo nor me are going. Manjeet will be covering for us with regards to DVR. I want to at least be available on IRC while you guys meet so some conversation can be had.

Let's discuss at the PTG, I have a DVR session proposed and this is one of the topics I want to hit on. There should be some level of basic level of parity we aim for, and that should be spelled out.

In my opinion, some of these things like fast-exit and address scopes aren't really "features" per se and are more like basic functionality. As such, I don't view address scopes as optional given the contract that the ML2 plugin makes by implementing the extension. With regard to DVR fast-exit, the reason that we came back and added it as a "feature" is because the design of DVR was lacking from the start. I don't want to make that mistake here, packet flow in and out of compute nodes is a basic thing to have nailed down before proceeding.

To me, there are things that have to be a part of the basic design that we should not settle for iterating towards. Those need to be identified and spelled out here, I think the PTG is a perfect forum for jump-starting this conversation.

git_review/cmd.py.message:
To reference the target branch probably better to use:

 git log %s --decorate --oneline HEAD --not %s/%s

Rather than using the --remotes option.

Currently it lists only changes that would be submitted for actual reviews, and anything that would be pulled in by a merge is ignored. Changing to this would included listing anything behind a merge that is not on the target branch but would be included by submitting a merge.

Is that likely to cause some confusion? In suggesting that many more changes are being submitted for review than actually will be?


Suggest instead that two commands be used to distinguish between what will be submitted for review and what will be included automatically from another branch in the remote since the SHA1 already exists.

List changes being submitted for review only:

 git log --color --decorate --oneline HEAD --not --remotes=<remote>

skip_lines=<Get number of lines from previous command>
List changes that will be included from existing branches in the remote by this review:

 git log --color --decorate --oneline remote/<branch>..HEAD | tail -n $((1+${skip_lines}))


Bit of work to iterate over and find the correct point, but the first command would certainly tell you how many commits are going to be submitted for review, and then the additional commits showing up in the second command without the tail would show any commits being pulled in from other branches.

Another alternative that I thought about after Sydney was using a federation but without a mapping.

For example, what if each keystone node federated with Active Directory (if AD issues SAML). But instead of automatically mapping those users into groups with role assignments, you leave the mapping empty. This means users would be able to authenticate to keystone in eu-west and eu-east, but they can only authenticate initially. After words, an administrator would be grant them access to projects within that region or regions.

Active Directory would still be the source of authentication, but there wouldn't be any authorization information implied in OpenStack. Instead, all the authorization information comes from role assignments given to the user after they authenticate for the first time. Each region still has its own keystone, which isn't replicated with other keystone nodes.

To clarify, this means that if a role assignment is removed from one region that causes a token to be revoked, there is nothing stopping that token from being valid in another region.

- User get's token scoped to project 7284841cb8294661b694dc0ee8fdd895 in eu-west region
- User creates instancess in eu-west region
- User creates volumes and instances in eu-east region
- User is removed from project 7284841cb8294661b694dc0ee8fdd895 in eu-west region
- User can no longer manage any resources in eu-west
- User can still manage anything they created in eu-east because they still have a role assignment on project 7284841cb8294661b694dc0ee8fdd895
If deployers want to use this, they are also on the hook to do the replication manually using this API.

guidelines/cloud-profile.rst.message:
Not sure how many people have been around long enough to remember all the release names. Maybe say something like "with an OpenStack deployment from 2010"? 

Also, you should have capitalized 'Bexar' :-P

I'm not entirely comfortable with the entries from here to the end of the section. It effectively  duplicates the service catalog.

It's perhaps the case that in a just universe this is how it would have been from the start (service catalog as static doc in well-known location).

But it wasn't that universe and now this is duplication, which is weird somehow.

So is it fair to say that this would have been ideal to have from the start, but a different path was chosen? That path has turned out to be less that ideal for the examples given above, such as CLIs, so adding a profile document like this helps to address that shortcoming, and the partial duplication of information is an unavoidable consequence.

SO - it both is and isn't a duplicate of the service catalog.

It's different in that it's global, not per-user. So a user can have more services in their catalog than what are listed here. It's also different in that it's cached copies of the version discovery documents.

This means that a consumer fetches the profile once per cloud and then can do all of the correct logic re: version discovery without having to deal with calculating cost for doing that vs. hard-coding version endpoints. (real story - python-neutronclient just har-codes a + '/v2.0' to the url from the catalog because why would they hit their version discovery endpoint)

This is especially important for things like cli's, where there is no great way to do in-process caches of lookup data, since it's a new process each time. BUT - the only time this data changes is when a deployer rolls out a new version of their cloud, so at the moment there are a ton of user API calls to find out information that doesn't change.

The catalog is still important. It's how a cloud can give a user access to services that are not generally available. Since all the profile is is a cache of data that comes from the version discovery endpoints of the services in the basic catalog, a user with a service in their catalog that isn't in the profile can still use it- it'll just require a couple more API calls.

It can also contain the etag of the profile so that the client knows it needs to fetch a new copy of the profile.

But the cached data here winds up being really important, otherwise discovery is too expensive to be consistently used, and we wind up with a bazillion hacks in all of the client libs trying to find the times when one _actually_ needs to fetch discovery.

author.name: Chris Hoge (not involved in upstream development)

I recognize that that's ignoring the fact that there's a real problem _now_ that needs to be solved but it would be good that if we're going to formalize this stuff we might formalize it in a way that says "everything here is pragmatic but deprecated".

_Or_ we should decide that service level capabilities are something we're not going to do and we should do it here, one or the other, not both.

Well, I'd love to see services add all of these capabilities - but them doing that isn't backportable for folks running older openstacks, whereas having a document that could be deployed (or could be made and downloaded ad-hoc like we do now in os-client-config) gets us a possible path to improving things for all of our users, not just the ones we'll get tomorrow.

So I totally agree with the sentiment ... perhaps the path is: we put them in here for now, but since there are already some things (versions) that are generated from hitting discovery URLs, over time the file generation tool could start filling in data from the services themselves and there would be even less the operator has to put into their little template document. (which matches what you're suggesting with pragmatic-but-deprecated)

and perhaps the thing that is deprecated is "the need to fill in any data in this file manually by the operator"

I think it's still valuable to have the top-level file, just like it's valuable to have the cached collection of version discovery documents - largely because there's a ton of API usage that happens from shell scripts or ansible/salt type environments, where each interaction is an island that doesn't have any shared execution context with previous interactions. When we have a pile of services and a pile of capabilities, that's awesome as a true canonical source, but it's fairly horrible from a caching perspective - or it winds up with clients making a pile of calls at the start of every command to learn/validate information that will mostly never change. It _can_ be cached locally after being discovered, but then that's offloading the work to implement fetching and caching and invalidation of each service's version and capabilities discovery information onto every client library and every application ... and now people are sad. (this is one of the main pushbacks towards getting unversioned discovery urls into the keystone catalog - the fear that, even though it's a more complete and correct setup, it's introducing additional roundtrips that will be made every time.

Because these distinctions have served us so well in the endpoint lists.  Both uses are theoretically "behind-the-scenes" and for special use cases (services and admins) so I'd rather just say alternate realities can be exposed via profile-XXXXX.json and not pre-plant the idea that these particular two need to be propagated.

No, if they are receiving 5xx, there are bigger problems. What I mean is that some implementations will return 404 Not Found if the resource doesn't exist. I'll update the language.

I'm sorry, this, to me, is completely wrong, and this is one of the hills I will die on.

If a URI is well-formed, it is platonically valid, and thus should be a 404 if there is no resource with that identity at the target host. That is the absolute root principle of HTTP and to say otherwise would completely kill any claims we have to credibility.

    DELETE /invalid_resource_type/{uuid}

must be a 404 exactly because

   GET /invalid_resource_type/{uuid}

must be a 404.

Where there is room to quibble is when query parameters get involved, but for so-called "paths" only, there isn't.

The idempotency argument can be used to support my position: DELETE /invalid_resource_type/{uuid} should always be 404, because there is no point in time in the current definition of resource reality at which it could ever be a 200 when GET. Or to turn it inside out: If DELETE wasn't idempotent, there's no situation where a DELETE that had a 204 could then become a 404 because it would always be 404: It can't ever be there. It's not an inavlid URI, it's just not here (it might be somewhere else).


The fundamental principle I'm working from here is that the thing that matters the most in all of HTTP is the URI. It is _the_ thing that matters.

So let me rephrase what you're saying to make sure I'm following. Given the following URI:

 /resource_type/resource_id

we will first validate that `resource_type` is valid (i.e., something the system can understand). If not, return a 404 no matter what method is called on it.

If `resource_type` is understandable by the system, any call to DELETE will never return 404.

Is that accurate?

> we will first validate that `resource_type` is valid (i.e.,
 > something the system can understand). If not, return a 404 no
 > matter what method is called on it.

Sort of, that's how the web works, as a general rule.

In most implementations it is built into whatever the routing or dispatching tool is: if a URI matches to the map you proceed deeper into the system. If the URI doesn't match, you get a 404.

With the caveat that the URI is the entire thing, not some chunk of it. There is no 'resource_type'. There is '/resource_type/resource_id'.
I disagree that this interpretation is practical, even if it's more correct from theoretical standpoint.
